title: Ancient Clay Lamp
short_label: Clay oil lamp with single nozzle
base_context: This small clay oil lamp was used in daily life for domestic lighting. It comes from a Roman-era household in the Eastern Mediterranean and reflects common motifs of the time.

title: Bronze Helmet
short_label: Bronze war helmet from Greek hoplite
base_context: This bronze helmet belonged to a Greek infantry soldier (hoplite). It shows battle wear and was found near an ancient battlefield. It illustrates protective technology and craftsmanship of Classical Greece.

title: Torah Crown
base_context: A Torah crown used to adorn the Torah scroll in synagogues. It is richly decorated with floral motifs and small bells, representing honour and reverence for the sacred text.

title: Mona Lisa
short_label: Portrait of a woman with enigmatic smile
base_context: Leonardo da Vinci’s most famous portrait, believed to depict Lisa Gherardini of Florence. The painting is celebrated for its subtle sfumato technique, atmospheric background, and the sitter’s ambiguous expression that has intrigued viewers for centuries.

title: The Last Supper
short_label: Christ’s final meal with the apostles
base_context: Leonardo da Vinci’s monumental wall painting showing Jesus announcing that one disciple will betray him. The work is renowned for its dramatic composition, use of perspective, and the expressive reactions of each apostle at the table.

title: Napoleon Crossing the Alps
short_label: Heroic portrait of Napoleon on horseback
base_context: Painted by Jacques-Louis David, this work presents Napoleon as a calm, commanding leader astride a rearing horse, allegedly crossing the Great St. Bernard Pass. It is a powerful piece of political propaganda that emphasizes courage, control, and destiny.

title: The Starry Night
short_label: Swirling night sky over a village
base_context: Vincent van Gogh’s iconic nocturne painted while he was in an asylum at Saint-Rémy. The swirling stars, exaggerated crescent moon, and dramatic sky express the artist’s emotional and spiritual turmoil as much as the landscape itself.

title: Girl with a Pearl Earring
short_label: Young woman in turban with large earring
base_context: Johannes Vermeer’s intimate tronie of a young woman turned toward the viewer. The luminous pearl, soft lighting, and deep blue and yellow turban create a striking sense of immediacy, earning it the nickname “the Mona Lisa of the North.”

title: The Night Watch
short_label: Militia company preparing to move out
base_context: Rembrandt’s large group portrait of Captain Frans Banning Cocq and his civic militia. Dynamic lighting, dramatic poses, and deep shadows turn what could have been a static line-up into a lively scene of movement and tension.

title: The Persistence of Memory
short_label: Melting clocks in a desolate landscape
base_context: Salvador Dalí’s dreamlike painting where soft, drooping clocks lie over strange organic forms and a barren seashore. The work explores the fluidity of time and the subconscious, becoming a key symbol of Surrealism.

title: The Birth of Venus
short_label: Goddess Venus emerging from the sea
base_context: Sandro Botticelli’s mythological scene shows Venus standing on a shell, blown ashore by winds as nymphs wait to receive her. The painting combines classical themes with graceful, linear figures and delicate pastel colours.

title: Guernica
short_label: Distorted figures in a war-torn interior
base_context: Pablo Picasso’s monumental anti-war painting created in response to the bombing of the town of Guernica during the Spanish Civil War. Fragmented figures, screaming horses, and stark black-and-white tones convey chaos, suffering, and protest.

title: American Gothic
short_label: Farmer and daughter standing with pitchfork
base_context: Grant Wood’s famous double portrait of a stern farmer and a woman in front of a Carpenter Gothic farmhouse. Often read as a symbol of Midwestern resilience, it has also been widely parodied in popular culture.

title: The School of Athens
base_context: Raphael’s grand fresco depicting Plato, Aristotle, and other ancient thinkers in a vast architectural space. The painting celebrates philosophy and rational inquiry, using perspective and carefully arranged groups to guide the viewer’s eye.

title: The Kiss
material: Oil and gold leaf on canvas
base_context: Gustav Klimt’s intimate scene of two lovers wrapped in intricate golden patterns. The sparkling surface, stylized forms, and decorative motifs make it a hallmark of fin-de-siècle Viennese art.
